description: From Middle English senvey, senevey, from Old French senevé, senevei, from Vulgar Latin *sināpātium, from Latin sināpi (→ Old French senef), from Ancient Greek σίνᾱπι (sínāpi).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The mustard plant or its seed.
examples: The wheat seemed to have disappeared, to make room for a prodigious quantity of senvy which looked extremely well.
